title: If I’m an Egyptian today, where were my ancestors from? - Quora

response.answer_text: How far back do you want to go? A modern Egyptian could literally have ancestors from anywhere in the world. If you go as far back as the first hominid, then we're talking about the area of the Great Rift Valley. All humans have ancestors from that region. Going back billions of years, all we can say us ‘somewhere on earth, probably a geothermal vent'. Ultimately, our ancestors, in the sense of everything we are, came from the universe.

Most modern Egyptians, especially in the north, derive their ancestry from outside of the African continent. Quote: “Using ADMIXTURE and principal-component analysis (PCA)(Figure 1A), we estimated the average proportion of non-African ancestry in the Egyptians to be 80% and dated the midpoint of the admixture event by using ALDER to around 750 years ago (Table S2), consistent with the Islamic expansion and dates reported previously.” Tracing the Route of Modern Humans out of Africa by Using 225 Human Genome Sequences from Ethiopians and Egyptians So based on genetics, most Egyptians are only 20% African and the other 80% is foreign, arriving with Arab expansion.
